captions.text: I thought I told you never to come in here.
Well, it's going to cost you.
How much money you got on you?
GEORGE: How much do you want, Biff?

- Now I'm going to...
- Biff. What's that?
That's Calvin Klein. My God, he's a dream.
MARTY: I'll get it back to you.

GIRL: What's that thing he's on?
BOY: A board with wheels.

THUG 1: Come on, come on!
THUG 2: Look out for the car!
BIFF: I'm going to ram him.
I'm going to get that son of a bitch.

- Where does he come from?
- Yeah, where does he live?

title: Back to the Future (7/10) Movie CLIP - Skateboard Chase (1985) HD

comments.author: Chris Wilkerson

comments.text:
After watching this film 30173983674 times I feel like it's time to ruin 
this scene once and for all...

0:01 Why does everyone suddenly care about Biff's annoyance with George? Is 
it so Robert Zemeckis could have a funny scene?

0:17 Biff is clearly walking slighly more to the right than he was in the 
previous shot.

Pause exactly at 0:20 as he lands. That face 😮

0:31 That is not Michael J. Fox. He has grown several inches and has more 
hair. Possibly Eric Stoltz.

0:43 The backwards hat kid is trying to get Marty off the scooter and then 
is calmly watching him in the next shot. 

1:02 Look at the back of the board and keep it in mind for later. 

The car changes from a 1946 to a 1948 Ford throughout the scene.

1:27 Shouldn't there be future ramifications for destroying that hedge? The 
money it costs to repair it, and somebody in a car having to wait 10 
seconds for the hedge guy person to cross the road?

1:54 That Yellow car came from nowhere.

1:55 And now it is gone.

2:03 "I'm gonna ram him." Geez. I knew Biff was a bully, but not a 
homicidal one.

2:07 Obviously not Michael J. Fox.

2:09 The spark emitter on the back of the board is gone all of a sudden.

2:10"SHIIIIIIIIIIIIIT!!" That is Billy Zane's only line in the film. WHY, 
BOB GALE?!?!?!?!??!

2:12 Use the radio antennae as a reference point. The car has slightly 
moved backwards from when it hits the truck, to the manure dumping on the 
gang.

2:28 The striped shirt kid teleports between cuts.

Apparently Marty's purple shirt changes color throughout the scene, but I 
javen't noticed.

How were the police not involved with this incident? Lorraine can track and 
follow Marty back to Doc's place but not the authorities?

Oh, and see if you can spot Thomas F. Wilson's stunt driver throughout the 
scene.﻿

comments.author: luis monreal

comments.text:
What are the future ramifications of those hedges being knocked over? That 
cost money, which changed history.

And how is it the cops didn't get involved in this? A guy tries to run 
someone over and then crashes into a manure truck and no boys in blue have 
any questions? Biff gets into no trouble for trying to kill someone or for 
the damage he caused to the manure truck and to the center of town? And 
meanwhile the cops don't find Marty but Lorraine does?﻿

1955, saying "I'm going to ram him!" has every intent to kill.  Marty 
punched Biff and ran, but instead of just a fist fight, Biff wants to 
murder Marty.  I know Marty wouldn't want to draw too much attention to 
himself with any trial or anything, and he was hoping to be gone by the end 
of the week, but still, where were the police?﻿

comments.author: BTTFMovie

comments.text: So I take it you wouldn't want to be stranded there either?
comments.author: daustin8888

comments.text:
+daustin8888 Eh, I think it was a simpler time for the people in charge. 
People who grew up during that time most likely look back on it through 
rose-tinted glasses.

The draft was still instated, there was a constant fear of nuclear war, 
cases of rape and child molestation were rarely reported, no rebellious 
teenagers (at least no one knew they were), and anyone who was "different" 
(gay, transgender, mixed race, etc.) had to try to hide it while everyone 
else accepted their role in society without ever questioning authority.

It was easier to make a livelihood (if you were white), I suppose, but for 
the most part, I'd say only super conservatives would think of the 50's as 
the good ol' days.
comments.author: BTTFMovie

comments.text:
It was a simpler time to a certain degree. You didn't have to worry about 
terrorism, people still trusted politicians, and being patriotic wasn't 
taboo. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't perfect (being an African Americans I 
would not want to be stranded in that decade), but it was a wonderful time 
to be alive and American.
comments.author: daustin8888
